Eureka ML Insights
  • eureka_ml_insights.metrics package
  • Edit on GitHub

eureka_ml_insights.metrics package

Submodules

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.aime_metrics module

This module provides a metric class for checking the numerical match between two string representations of numeric values.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.aime_metrics.NumericMatch(model_output_col='model_output')

Bases: ClassicMetric

NumericMatch class.

This metric class checks the numerical match between answer_text and target_text within a margin of eps.

eps

Tolerance for the difference between numerical values.

Type:

float

eps = 1e-06

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ba_calendar_metrics module

This module provides functionality for validating and scoring meeting time slot solutions against specified constraints. It includes helper functions for parsing and filtering time slots, and a composite metric class (BACalendarMetric) that checks the solution format, availability, meeting duration, buffer time, weekend usage, time restrictions, specific times restrictions, and meeting priority.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ba_calendar_metrics.BACalendarMetric

Bases: CompositeMetric

A composite metric for evaluating if a response meets certain constraints.

This metric checks the response’s format, availability, meeting duration, buffer time, weekend usage, time restrictions, specific time restrictions, and meeting priority.

check_availability_programmatic(instance, solution)

Check whether the solution meets the availability constraints for all participants.

Parameters:

  • instance (dict) – The instance containing metadata (including availability) and constraints.

  • solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot.

Returns:

A dictionary with the availability check result (1 or 0, or None if N/A).

Return type:

dict

check_buffer_time_programmatic(instance, solution)

Check if the solution respects the required buffer time before and after the meeting.

Parameters:

  • instance (dict) – The instance containing constraints (including buffer_time_before_and_after_meeting).

  • solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot.

Returns:

A dictionary with the buffer time check result (1 or 0, or None if N/A).

Return type:

dict

check_meeting_duration_programmatic(instance, solution)

Check if the proposed solution’s meeting duration matches the expected duration.

Parameters:

  • instance (dict) – The instance containing constraints (including meeting_duration).

  • solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot.

Returns:

A dictionary with the meeting duration check result (1 or 0, or None if N/A).

Return type:

dict

check_no_weekends_programmatic(instance, solution)

Check if the proposed solution does not fall on weekends, if that constraint is required.

Parameters:

  • instance (dict) – The instance containing constraints (including no_meetings_on_weekends).

  • solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot.

Returns:

A dictionary with the weekend check result (1 or 0, or None if N/A).

Return type:

dict

check_priority_programmatic(instance, solution)

Check if the proposed solution meets the high-priority meeting constraint, if enabled.

This involves ensuring the selected time slot is the earliest possible slot that meets all constraints.

Parameters:

  • instance (dict) – The instance containing constraints, metadata, and parameters.

  • solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot.

Returns:

A dictionary indicating if the proposed solution meets the priority constraints.

Return type:

dict

check_specific_times_programmatic(instance, solution)

Check if the proposed solution avoids times when meetings are disallowed.

Parameters:

  • instance (dict) – The instance containing constraints (including no_meetings_during_specific_times).

  • solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot.

Returns:

A dictionary indicating if the specific times constraint is satisfied.

Return type:

dict

check_time_restrictions_programmatic(instance, solution)

Check if the proposed solution adheres to the no_meetings_before and no_meetings_after constraints.

Parameters:

  • instance (dict) – The instance containing constraints for time restrictions.

  • solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot.

Returns:

A dictionary indicating if the time restrictions are satisfied.

Return type:

dict

compute_constrainedness_programmatic(instance)

Compute the problem’s constrainedness based on constraints and availability.

Constrainedness is defined as (1 - the ratio of feasible slots to total slots). The higher the constrainedness, the more constrained the problem is. The result is also bucketed into intervals of 0.1.

Parameters:

instance (dict) – The instance containing constraints, availability, and parameters.

Returns:

A dictionary containing ‘constrainedness’ and ‘constrainedness_bucket’.

Return type:

dict

is_formatted(solution)

Check if the proposed solution is in the correct format.

Parameters:

solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot string.

Returns:

True if the solution is correctly formatted, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

run_programmatic_tests(instance)

Run programmatic tests for the provided instance.

Parameters:

instance (dict) – The instance containing the solution and constraints.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the outcomes of all programmatic checks.

Return type:

dict

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ba_calendar_metrics.check_time_slot_format(solution)

Check if the provided solution string matches the required time slot format.

The format is: (Monday|Tuesday|Wednesday|Thursday|Friday|Saturday|Sunday) HH:MM-HH:MM

Parameters:

solution (str) – The proposed meeting time slot string.

Returns:

True if it matches the required format, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ba_calendar_metrics.filter_slots_by_constraints(time_slots, constraints, day)

Filter the given time slots by various constraints (no meetings before/after, no meetings on weekends, no meetings during specific times).

Parameters:

  • time_slots (list) – A list of tuples (start_time, end_time) representing slots.

  • constraints (dict) – A dictionary containing various meeting constraints.

  • day (str) – The day of the week for the given time slots.

Returns:

A list of tuples (start_time, end_time) that satisfy all constraints.

Return type:

list

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ba_calendar_metrics.filter_slots_by_duration(time_slots, duration)

Filter time slots by ensuring at least the specified duration from a starting slot.

Parameters:

  • time_slots (list) – A list of tuples (start, end) for time slots.

  • duration (int) – Required minimum duration in minutes.

Returns:

A list of tuples (start, end) that meet the minimum duration requirement.

Return type:

list

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ba_calendar_metrics.generate_time_slots(start_time, end_time, granularity)

Generate time slots of a given granularity between start_time and end_time.

Parameters:

  • start_time (datetime) – The start datetime.

  • end_time (datetime) – The end datetime.

  • granularity (int) – The size of each slot in minutes.

Returns:

A list of tuples representing start and end times for each slot.

Return type:

list

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ba_calendar_metrics.parse_time_block(time_block)

Parse a string time block in the format ‘HH:MM-HH:MM’ into datetime objects.

Parameters:

time_block (str) – The string representing a time block.

Returns:

A tuple of two datetime objects (start_time, end_time).

Return type:

tuple

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.f1score_metrics module

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.f1score_metrics.MaxTokenF1ScoreMetric(model_output_col='model_output')

Bases: ClassicMetric

A metric for calculating the maximum token-based F1 score across multiple ground truth answers.

tokenize(sentence)

Tokenize the input sentence into a list of word tokens.

Parameters:

sentence (str) – The input sentence to tokenize.

Returns:

A list of tokens extracted from the sentence.

Return type:

list

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.geomtric_reasoning_metrics module

Module containing the GeoMCQMetric class for evaluating multiple-choice questions.

GeoMCQMetric is derived from SpatialAndLayoutReasoningMetric and enforces that a correct prediction must be one of the valid multiple-choice options.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.geomtric_reasoning_metrics.GeoMCQMetric

Bases: SpatialAndLayoutReasoningMetric

A metric that requires a correct prediction to be only one of the valid multiple-choice answers.

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_instruction_utils module

Utility library of instructions.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_instruction_utils.BulletListChecker(instruction_id)

Bases: Instruction

Checks the bullet list in the prompt.

build_description(*, num_bullets=None)

Build the instruction description.

Parameters:

num_bullets – An integer specifying the exact number of bullet lists that is required to appear in the response.

Returns:

A string representing the instruction description.

check_following(value)

Check if the number of bullet lists meets the requirement.

Parameters:

value – A string representing the response. The response is expected to contain some bullet lists that start with *.

Returns:

True if the actual number of bullet lists in the response meets the requirement.

get_instruction_args()

Returns the keyward args of build_description.

get_instruction_args_keys()

Returns the args keys of build_description.

Build the instruction description.

Parameters:

  • capital_relation – A string that is ‘at least’ or ‘at most’ that refers to the frequency.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_instruction_utils.KeywordFrequencyChecker(instruction_id)

Bases: Instruction

Check the keyword frequency.

build_description(*, keyword=None, frequency=None, relation=None)

Build the instruction description.

Parameters:

  • keyword – A string representing a keyword that is expected in the response.

  • frequency – An integer specifying the number of times keyword is expected to appear in the response.

  • relation – A string in (less than, at least), defining the relational operator for comparison. Two relational comparisons are supported for now: if ‘less than’, the actual number of occurrences < frequency; if ‘at least’, the actual number of occurrences >= frequency.

Returns:

A string representing the instruction description.

check_following(value)

Checks if the response contain the keyword with required frequency.

get_instruction_args()

Returns the keyward args of build_description.

get_instruction_args_keys()

Returns the args keys of build_description.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_instruction_utils.ParagraphFirstWordCheck(instruction_id)

Bases: Instruction

build_description(num_paragraphs=None, nth_paragraph=None, first_word=None)

Build the instruction description.

Parameters:

  • num_paragraphs – An integer indicating the number of paragraphs expected in the response. A paragraph is a subset of the string that is expected to be separated by ‘nn’.

  • nth_paragraph – An integer indicating the paragraph number that we look at. Note that n starts from 1.

  • first_word – A string that represent the first word of the bth paragraph.

Returns:

A string representing the instruction description.

Checks for required number of paragraphs and correct first word.

Parameters:

value – a string representing the response. The response may contain paragraphs that are separated by two new lines and the first word of the nth paragraph will have to match a specified word.

Returns:

True if the number of paragraphs is the same as required and the first word of the specified paragraph is the same as required. Otherwise, false.

Build the instruction description.

Parameters:

original_message – A string representing the original message. The rephrased response should only change its words/sentences in between its two asterisks, for example, change me. Both original and rephrased messages should contain the changes in the form of change me.

value – A string representing the response, which is expected to rephras the string of instruction_args.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_instruction_utils.ResponseLanguageChecker(instruction_id)

Bases: Instruction

Check the language of the entire response.

build_description(*, language=None)

Build the instruction description.

Parameters:

language – A string representing the expected language of the response. The language has to comply to the 97 types defined in langid.py (https://pypi.org/project/langid/1.1.5/), which follows ISO 639-1 codes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes); for example, en for English, zh for Chinese, fr for French.

Returns:

A string representing the instruction description.

check_following(value)

value – A string representing the response.

Returns:

True if the language of value follows instruction; otherwise False.

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_instruction_utils.conflict_make(conflicts)

Makes sure if A conflicts with B, B will conflict with A.

Parameters:

conflicts – Dictionary of potential conflicts where key is instruction id and value is set of instruction ids that it conflicts with.

Returns:

Revised version of the dictionary. All instructions conflict with themselves. If A conflicts with B, B will conflict with A.

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_metrics module

This module provides the IFEvalMetric class for evaluating if a response follows instructions.

The IFEvalMetric extends the CompositeMetric class to measure compliance with instructions using both strict and loose evaluations.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.ifeval_metrics.IFEvalMetric

Bases: CompositeMetric

Composite metric for evaluating if a response follows instructions.

This class calculates both strict and loose evaluation scores based on the response’s adherence to the instructions by leveraging the CompositeMetric base class.

evaluate_instruction_following(row, include_loose_evaluation=True)

Evaluates instruction following for a given row.

Parameters:

  • row (dict) – The dictionary containing ‘prompt’, ‘response’, ‘instruction_id_list’, ‘kwargs’, and other relevant data.

  • include_loose_evaluation (bool) – Whether to include loose evaluation in addition to strict evaluation. Defaults to True.

Returns:

A dictionary combining the results from strict evaluation and, if enabled, loose evaluation.

Return type:

dict

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.kitab_metrics module

This module provides the KitabMetric class for evaluating constraints on textual data, including checking for human names, city names, word counts, publishing years, etc. It leverages the Azure Language Service for entity recognition and fuzzy matching for approximate checks. It also relies on GPT-4 preprocessed human names to validate titles. Metrics such as completeness, correctness, and constrainedness are computed to aid in the assessment of model-generated outputs against ground truth data.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.kitab_metrics.KitabMetric(temp_path_names, azure_lang_service_config)

Bases: CompositeMetric

A metric class that extends CompositeMetric to evaluate constraints on text dataset rows. This includes checking for author correctness, constraints such as word counts, human names, city names, and data completeness.

compute_satisfaction_unsatisfaction(existing_titles_model_titles, single_constraint, constraint_type, all_books, str_all_books)

Determines which titles satisfy or do not satisfy a single constraint.

Parameters:

  • existing_titles_model_titles (dict) – A mapping from recognized titles to lists of model books.

  • single_constraint (str) – The textual representation of the constraint (e.g., “starts with J.”).

  • constraint_type (str) – The type of constraint (e.g., “starts-with”).

  • all_books (list) – A list of all possible books (processed titles).

  • str_all_books (str) – A string representation of all books, used for year parsing.

Returns:

A dictionary with two keys:

”satisfied”: A list of titles that satisfy the constraint. “unsatisfied”: A list of titles that do not satisfy the constraint.

Return type:

dict

extract_cities(text)

Extracts city names mentioned in the input text using Azure Text Analytics and an external data source that verifies city existence.

Parameters:

text (str) – Input text containing city names.

Returns:

A list of extracted city names. The function checks recognized location entities against a public API for city data.

Return type:

list

A list of extracted person names.

fuzzy_compare(title, list_of_title, threshold=90)

Performs fuzzy string comparison between the input title and a list of titles, checking for approximate matches above a given threshold.

Parameters:

  • title (str) – Input book title to compare.

  • list_of_title (list) – A list of book titles against which to compare.

  • threshold (int, optional) – Minimum similarity score required for a match (default is 90).

Returns:

A tuple with a boolean indicating if a match was found and the matched title (if any). For example, (True, ‘Matching Title’) or (False, ‘’).

Return type:

tuple

get_verified_credential()

Attempts to create and validate a credential for the Azure Text Analytics Client. Tries first AzureKeyCredential, then DefaultAzureCredential as a fallback, returning either one if successful.

Returns:

A verified credential for the Azure

Text Analytics if successfully created, otherwise None.

Return type:

AzureKeyCredential or DefaultAzureCredential

Processes a row of data to identify correct, incorrect, and hallucinated book titles based on given constraints.

  • row (dict) – A dictionary containing the input row data with keys: ‘mapped_books’, ‘model_books’, ‘all_books’, ‘raw_books’, ‘constraint_type’, and ‘constraints’.

  • gpt4_names (list) – A list of human names used by the GPT-4 model for comparison.

Returns:

dict

Processes a book title by converting it to lowercase, replacing ‘&’ with ‘and’, removing punctuation, and excluding common starting words (‘the’, ‘a’, ‘an’).

Parameters:

title (str) – Input book title.

Returns:

Processed book title.

Return type:

str

stopwords = {'a', 'an', 'and', 'for', 'in', 'is', 'of', 'on', 'the', 'to', 'with'}

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.metrics_base.Metric

Bases: object

Base class for metrics.

This class defines the core structure for validating data and evaluating a metric on a given dataset. Subclasses should implement the __evaluate__ method.

Module that provides MMMUMetric class for evaluating multiple-choice and open-ended questions from the MMMU dataset.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.mmmu_metrics.MMMUMetric

Bases: MixedQuestionTypeMetric

Implements the exact metric from the MMMU dataset for multiple-choice and open-ended answers.

The original code is located at: https://github.com/MMMU-Benchmark/MMMU/tree/main/eval/utils and includes small modifications to work in this framework.

get_multi_choice_info(options)

Generates a mapping and list of choice indices for multiple-choice questions.

Parameters:

options (list of str) – A list of multiple-choice options.

Returns:

A tuple (index2ans, all_choices) where:

index2ans (dict): Maps a choice index (e.g., ‘A’) to the corresponding option text. all_choices (list of str): A list of choice indices (e.g., [‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’, …]).

Return type:

tuple

normalize_str(string)

Normalizes a string to lowercase or converts it to a float if it looks like a number.

If the string is a number, it is converted to float and rounded to two decimals. If it is a single character, variants with leading and trailing spaces are returned to avoid trivial matches.

Parameters:

string (str) – The string to normalize.

Returns:

A list containing either the normalized string(s) or float value(s).

Return type:

list

parse_multi_choice_response(response, all_choices, index2ans)

Parses the prediction from the generated response and returns the predicted index.

This method validates the response content to identify the best matching multiple-choice index (e.g., ‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’, ‘D’). If no matching index is found, one is randomly chosen.

Parameters:

  • response (str) – The model-generated response.

  • all_choices (List[str]) – A list of possible choice indices (e.g., [‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’, ‘D’]).

  • index2ans (Dict[str, str]) – A mapping from choice indices to full answer strings.

Returns:

The predicted choice index (e.g., ‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’, or ‘D’).

Return type:

str

parse_open_response(response)

Parses the prediction from a generated response and returns a list of predicted strings or numbers.

This method extracts key sub-responses, numerical values, and normalizes them. Duplicate values are removed.

Parameters:

response (str) – The model-generated response.

Returns:

A list of predicted strings or numbers.

Return type:

list

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.nphard_sat_metrics module

This module provides the NPHardSATMetric class for evaluating solutions to the SAT problem.

The NPHardSATMetric class inherits from Metric and determines whether a model-predicted assignment string is one of the optimal solutions, or whether both the prediction and ground truth indicate the problem is unsatisfiable.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.nphard_sat_metrics.NPHardSATMetric

Bases: Metric

NPHardSATMetric class for evaluating solutions to SAT problems.

A prediction is considered correct if it is a valid SAT assignment that matches one of the optimal solutions, or if both the model output and ground truth indicate unsatisfiable.

is_assignment_optimal(optimal_assignment_list, assignment_string)

Determines whether a model-predicted assignment string is accepted as a correct SAT solution.

Parameters:

  • optimal_assignment_list (List[str]) – A list of canonical optimal assignments, each expressed as a comma-separated string of 0/1 literals, following the variable order specified in the prompt instructions (e.g. “1,0,1,1”). An empty list ([]) represents “unsatisfiable.”

  • assignment_string (str) – The model’s prediction in the same 0/1 comma-separated format. An empty string (“”) means the model declares “unsatisfiable.”

Normalization:

This function removes spaces and surrounding parentheses from every entry in optimal_assignment_list, then rejoins tokens with single commas. For example, “(1, 0 ,1)” becomes “1,0,1”.

Acceptance Criteria:

  1. Returns True if both sides claim unsatisfiable (assignment_string == “” and optimal_assignment_list == []).

  2. Returns True if the canonical assignment_string exactly matches one element of the normalized optimal_assignment_list.

Otherwise, returns False.

Order Sensitivity:

Because matching is string-exact, variable order must match between prediction and ground truth.

Returns:

True if the predicted assignment is accepted as correct, otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.nphard_tsp_metrics module

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.nphard_tsp_metrics.NPHardTSPMetric

Bases: Metric

A metric class for evaluating solutions to the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP).

A prediction is considered correct if it is a valid TSP tour and matches one of the optimal solutions.

is_tour_present(optimal_tour_curr, tour_string)

Checks if a given TSP tour is present in a list of optimal tours.

Parameters:

  • optimal_tour_curr (str) – A string representation of one or more optimal tours.

  • tour_string (str) – The predicted TSP tour, represented as a comma-separated string of city indices.

Returns:

True if the predicted tour is present among the optimal tours, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

is_valid_tsp_path(path, cities, distance_matrix=None)

Validates a TSP path and, if valid, evaluates its length.

Parameters:

  • path (list of int) – The TSP path, a list of city indices.

  • cities (list of int) – The list of all cities.

  • distance_matrix (list of lists, optional) – Matrix representing distances between cities.

Returns:

A tuple containing a boolean indicating whether the path is valid and a float for its total length if valid. Length is None if invalid.

Return type:

tuple(bool, float)

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.reports.AverageSTDDevAggregator(column_names, output_dir, group_by=None, ignore_non_numeric=False, filename_base=None, **kwargs)

Bases: NumericalAggregator

Aggregates data by computing both the average and standard deviation for numeric columns.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.reports.BiLevelAggregator(column_names, first_groupby, output_dir, second_groupby=None, agg_fn='mean', **kwargs)

Bases: AverageAggregator

Aggregates the data in two levels. First, it groups the data by the first_groupby column(s) and applies an aggregation function (agg_fn) on the specified columns. Then, if a second_groupby is specified, it groups the result again and computes the mean and standard deviation.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.reports.BiLevelCountAggregator(column_names, first_groupby, output_dir, normalize=False, second_groupby=None, **kwargs)

Bases: Aggregator

Aggregates the data in two levels. First, it groups the data by the first_groupby column(s) and applies a value_counts aggregation to each of the specified columns. Then, if a second_groupby is given, it groups the intermediate result again by the second_groupby column(s) and computes the mean and standard deviation of the counts.

Bases: Aggregator

Uses the COCO tools to calculate AP50 for provided detections.

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.spatial_and_layout_metrics module

This module provides a collection of metrics related to object detection, multiple-choice evaluation, and text analysis. It also offers utility functions for downloading NLTK resources and comparing words using WordNet path similarity.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.spatial_and_layout_metrics.CocoObjectDetectionMetric(target_coco_json_reader)

Bases: DetectionMetric

Implements parsing to prepare for COCO detection metrics.

The model output is parsed and formed into a COCO annotation, which is returned and stored as the metric output. The final statistics are computed in the CocoDetectionAggregator.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.spatial_and_layout_metrics.ObjectRecognitionMetric(model_output_col='model_output')

Bases: ClassicMetric

Implements a simple metric for object detection.

If any part of the target text (including one of the multiple words) appears in the answer text, the answer is considered correct.

class eureka_ml_insights.metrics.spatial_and_layout_metrics.SpatialAndLayoutReasoningMetric

Bases: MultipleChoiceMetric

SpatialAndLayoutReasoningMetric requires a correct prediction to be only one valid multiple choice answer.

This class inherits from MultipleChoiceMetric and checks whether only the correct option, among all the target options, is present exactly once in the answer text.

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.spatial_and_layout_metrics.download_nltk_resources()

Downloads the ‘wordnet’ corpus if it is not already installed.

This function attempts to locate the ‘wordnet’ corpus. If it is not found, it downloads the corpus using nltk.download.

eureka_ml_insights.metrics.spatial_and_layout_metrics.wordnet_compare(word, compare_word, threshold=1)

Compares two words for similarity using WordNet path similarity.

Parameters:

  • word (str) – The first word to compare.

  • compare_word (str) – The second word to compare with the first.

  • threshold (float, optional) – The similarity threshold required to consider the words matching. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

True if the maximum path similarity between any synsets of the two words is greater than or equal to the threshold, otherwise False.

Return type:

bool
